reviewText: Puppet Master III is the best of the Puppet Master series, at least thus far. I have yet to see a few of the later sequels, but if what I've read about them is true than they probably don't even come close to this one. Puppet Master III has a lot of action and some good gore. It also has some familiar faces that include Ian Abercrombie, Richard Lynch, and 80's b-horror queen Michelle Bauer. The main problem I had with this movie was that it was hard to understand a lot of the dialogue, either due to the sound or some thick German accents. That can be overlooked, though, when you have some fun puppets-killing-people action.
Title: N/A

reviewText: To begin, I'd like to claim that I've been a long-time fan of the 'Puppet Master' series. They are fun and original horror movies, which are also very rare to find nowadays (even on DVD!). The puppets are genuinely creepy, each in their own way (My two favorites have always been Blade and Tunneler) and the death sequences are executed nicely! Unlike the first two films, this one is actually a prequel taking place in 1940 Berlin, Germany, telling how it all began with puppeteer, Andre Toulon and the creation of his string-less [and murderous] puppets!During WWII, A German scientist, Dr. Hess (Ian Abercrombie) is trying to find the solution to re-animating life. Unfortunately  , his experiments always end in failure and his only hope lies from the wisdom of Toulon, himself, who's already figured out a way to bring the deceased back to life through his puppets. But Major Krauss (a convincingly cruel and coldhearted performance by Richard Lynch) grows impatient and takes Toulon's serum by force, thus killing his wife, Elsa (Sarah Douglas)! With the help of his puppets, Toulon exacts bloody revenge against Krauss and his officers! Here we get to see old favorites: Tunneler, Pin Head, the Leech Woman, Blade, and the newest to the batch, Six Shooter, a six armed wooden cowboy carrying a tiny revolver in each hand! As usual, each one does their job well, and for the first time, we get to catch a glimpse of how Blade was created!Without question, this could be considered the BEST 'Puppet Master' of all since the acting is slightly better and the plot more involving than that of the first two! Of course, #1 had always been my personal favorite, but after giving this one a couple watches, it's proved to actually be a lot better! In addition, Guy Rolfe does the PERFECT performance as Andre Toulon, who you cannot help but feel sorry for. I HIGHLY recommend this and the first two 'Puppet Master' films to ALL horror fans!!
summary: Probably the best 'Puppet Master' of them all!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This horror flick doesn't pretend to be anything but a simple revenge story, and I like that. There are no pretensions. "Toulon" (Guy Rolfe, replacing William Hickey who played the role the first two films) is the puppeteer-extraordinaire whose creations are literally lifelike.Rolfe and his deadly puppets go after the Nazis after they seek him out for his scientific genius of reanimating puppets. They want that information to use for their evil purposes so "Toulon" and his puppets fight back. It's sort of a do-it-to-them- before-they-do-it-to-us mentality. The head Nazi is played by Richard Lynch and the actor reminded me facially of Rutger Hauer.We see the Mr. Clean-type puppet with the little head and massive body; the puppet who "screws" everyone; the femme fatale and the cowboy "Six Shooter." There is probably someone I forgot, too. All are fun to watch.The plot is secondary to the puppets doing their thing, eliminating all the bad guys one-by-one and it's all entertaining and done with in less than an hour- and-a-half.If I could only own one Puppetmaster movie, this would be it. It's the best of the series.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is where the Puppet Master legacy begins-Andre Toulon's amazing discovery of bringing his puppets to life!It's World War II and the Nazis are conducting a variety of bizarre life and death experiments in an attempt to revive their dead and increase their manpower. The butcher in charge of this horrific plan in Gestapo henchman, Dr. Hess.When Hess learns that Toulon has found the secret of life, he sends Nazi soldiers to the puppet theatre to kidnap the puppeteer and his beloved creations. But in the process, Toulon's wife is murdered in cold blood.Toulon's revenge begins when the puppets strangle, drill, slash and shoot their way to freedom. While in hiding, Toulon uses his dead wife's life essence to create Leech Woman, the last of the hand-carved devils.Now the stage is set, as Six-Shooter, Blade, Tunneler, Pin Head, and the bloodthirsty Ms. Leech prepare for their own little war...

reviewText: As the years move on it becomes apparent how far we are removed from great B classics like the Puppet Master series. Now obviously these films have their flaws to most, but for the true B lover they are a much needed dose of enjoyment. If you were a young kid when these films sat on the video store shelf then you know what we're talking about. We'd actually have to say that Puppet Master III is far more enjoyable then the first or second installment. Now that may raise some eyebrows among the cult following masses, but honestly we found this one to really be a gem. Plus it had a generous dose Mr. Pitt throughout most of the viewing. Anytime you have an acting genius like Mr. Pitt nearly headlining the show, you're guaranteed to be here or it's free. Next stop Pottersville, next stop Pottersville.Puppet Master III, being a prequel, opens up in Berlin during World War II as the Nazis attempt to develop a serum to revive the dead. The man attempting to develop the serum is none other then scientist Mr. Pitt. If he's successful then he'll be rewarded by walking with the Woody Wood Pecker baloon in the Thanksgiving Day parade. No matter what he does he just can't perfect this concoction. Nearby is well known Puppet Master Andre Toulon who puts on a nice Hitler bashing puppet show, which angers the Nazi's. They have a spy go in who discovers Toulon's puppets are actually alive due to a serum he injects into them. Naturally the Nazi's raid Toulon's home, kill his wife, and steal batches of the serum. Unfortunately, for the Nazi's, they unleash the fury of Toulon who sends his puppets to exact revenge. They bring down the Nazi regime one by one in always entertaining fashion. Turns out that the Nazi's are never able to recreate the serum to any success. The puppets are alive because they actually have the souls of people Toulon used to be close with. Pretty creepy and awesome all at once.This one was a sure fire five star event with nothing negative to toss in. If you're enjoy Full Moon and the Puppet Master series, then this one should be a real treat. You'll be like Jo-Jo idiot circus boy with a pretty new pet. There is a great dose of that 90's B feel that will long for with each viewing. That is a factor that is not easy to accomplish unless the movie is the real deal, from a B horror standpoint. Another fine feature is the introduction to the puppet named Six Shooter. In addition to the usual cast, Six Shooter is like a mutant John Wayne with six arms and an appetite for gun fights. Plus he has this constant creepy deranged laugh anytime he's getting ready to lay somebody out. This is a series that really never needs to end. However we're not sure how the more recent ones hold up, but we'll find out. We dig, we test.

reviewText: In this third squel in the Puppet Master series,Andre Toulon once again is alive and has his little puppets with him.Taking place in Berlin,during World War II,the Nazis find out about Toulon's puppets and want to capture them for thier eltimate weapon against ememies.But Toulon won't allow them to take his puppets so Toulong runs away and teaches his puppets to kill all Nazis.This movie features a new puppet! In Puppet Master II it was "Torch" but now its "Six Shooter",Get this rare movie now! This is out of print. GET IT!
